replies.bodyText: You should add unit tests to check this behavior.
replies.author: kingthorin

timeline.bodyText: At this point you'll need to check if it is a JavaScript file and use msg.getResponseBody().toString() or if it's HTML and use the loop through script elements as you already have.
timeline.author: kingthorin

timeline.bodyText: Please use specific imports not wildcard.
timeline.author: kingthorin

@@ -0,0 +1,107 @@

+package org.zaproxy.zap.extension.pscanrulesAlpha;
+
+import static org.hamcrest.Matchers.empty;
+import static org.hamcrest.Matchers.hasSize;
+import static org.junit.Assert.*;

timeline.bodyText: You should add a test for one of the functions that has a leading $ since that is a significant regex char.
timeline.author: kingthorin

replies.bodyText:
While testing for this I realised that a search on $eval() using the regex pattern taken from the functions list $eval will fail but a match will be found if I used eval as the regex pattern instead. I have decided to amend the function list as such (refer to most recent commit).
Would like your opinion on whether this is the right direction to take, or whether I should relook at how my regex is formed, thanks!
replies.author: madanalogy

replies.bodyText: I think that's ok (doing it without the leading $)
replies.author: kingthorin

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                            0, // CWE Id - return 0 if no relevant one
          
          
            
                            749, // CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function
          
      
    
    
  

Or maybe: CWE-676: Use of Potentially Dangerous Function ?
timeline.author: kingthorin

timeline.bodyText: Do we really feel this is Alert.RISK_MEDIUM we're not checking or suggesting that they're using user input. It's probably more realistic to put it as Alert.RISK_LOW or Alert.RISK_INFO and even Alert.CONFIDENCE_LOW
timeline.author: kingthorin

replies.bodyText: Mmm what about Alert.RISK_INFO and Alert.CONFIDENCE_MEDIUM? Since it's informational but a matching pattern is very likely a function name since we only check the js?
replies.author: madanalogy

replies.bodyText:
Mmm what about Alert.RISK_INFO and Alert.CONFIDENCE_MEDIUM? Since it's informational but a matching pattern is very likely a function name since we only check the js?

Okay nevermind after adding eval and taking another look I realised some of the words might give false positive to function names so I'll switch to CONFIDENCE_LOW and RISK_LOW :)
replies.author: madanalogy

replies.bodyText: Sounds good.
replies.author: kingthorin

timeline.bodyText: This is misleading, the method already initialises the patterns. Might be better to change to createPatterns and not assign there.
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: The evidence field should not contain extraneous characters, it should match exactly what was found in the HTTP message. (It shouldn't be needed anyway, it's just using the first find.)
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: The length check could be added to the first if statement.
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: Minimised files will/might not have newlines, we should ensure the line is not too big when adding to the evidence.
timeline.author: thc202

replies.bodyText: And in the case it has many lines it might lead too much memory usage, might be better to find the whole content and just get chunks around the function found?
replies.author: thc202

replies.bodyText: You mean rather than initialise and iterate through lines, to just perform the pattern search on the raw text, i.e. remove call to split(\n)?
replies.author: madanalogy

replies.bodyText: Right.
replies.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: Same comment regarding the evidence (this might be better for the other info field too).
timeline.author: thc202

replies.bodyText: You mean split the call to Constant.messages.getString(MESSAGE_PREFIX + "otherinfo", pattern, line)); into a  separate variable to be displayed as other info rather than have it in the evidence?
replies.author: madanalogy

replies.bodyText: Yeah, but we could still use part of the "line" as evidence.
replies.author: thc202

replies.bodyText: I decided on removing the  "otherinfo" altogether as I didn't think it was necessary
replies.author: madanalogy

timeline.bodyText: Needs update.
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: Ideally this should be handled outside this method, otherwise the scanner will miss changes done to the payloads once the patterns is initialised.
timeline.author: thc202

replies.bodyText: Just wondering actually, how does the passive scan rule get notified when a new payload is uploaded? I didn't see an observer pattern anywhere and am largely basing my current payload implementation on what I could learn from other passive scan rules so I don't really understand it fully yet :")
replies.author: madanalogy

replies.bodyText: There's no notification, the provider always returns the latest payloads. It would be useful to tell that to cache the Patterns, but that will require changes in the Custom Payloads add-on.
replies.author: thc202

replies.bodyText: Hmm would it be possible then at every scan to check whether the payload has changed? Is there any built in change detection in Custom Payloads? If not I can just do a manual check
replies.author: madanalogy

replies.bodyText: There isn't, it would have to be done here. But for the first iteration I'd not add the check, just create the Patterns each time.
replies.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: I'd not add these, the test would fail anyway.
timeline.author: thc202

replies.bodyText: I don't quite get what you mean by this, are you referring to the test case or the specific assert method in this line?
replies.author: madanalogy

replies.bodyText: These (this line and following) specific assertions.
replies.author: thc202

timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: This will include the \bs also, we can use the group() from the Matcher which would return just the name of the function.
timeline.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText:
This should be extracted to a method, same for file and payloads.
The line needs to be quoted (Pattern#quote) to handle special regular expressions chars (worth adding a test for the file and custom payloads).
timeline.author: thc202

replies.bodyText:
During testing I noticed that it works so long as the special characters are not at the start or the end of the function names. For example, b$dFunction as an input pattern will match @b$dFunction() but $badFunction will not match $badFunction(). I'm thinking it should be fine as long as the behaviour is documented in the help page?
Alternatively I could just remove the word boundary \b during pattern compilation. I'm in favour of this implementation as it gives greater control to the user payload in exchange for a higher false positive rate which should be fine since the alert confidence is low.
replies.author: madanalogy

replies.bodyText: Sounds good.
replies.author: thc202

timeline.bodyText: Was this meant to be patterns = new HashSet(defaultPatterns);? Otherwise it will change the defaultPatterns.
timeline.author: thc202

replies.bodyText: Yes it was sorry, thanks for catching that!

timeline.bodyText: We could also use a list? I doubt we'll have many duplications that we require a set.
timeline.author: thc202

replies.bodyText: I'd rather stick to a Set for scalability, I feel that it's a worthy tradeoff since the only downside over using a List is non-deterministic iteration which only affects testing. I addressed that in my latest commit so am thinking it should be fine?
replies.author: madanalogy

replies.bodyText: What do you mean by scalability?
replies.author: thc202

replies.bodyText: If the function list grows or if the payload gets very big.
replies.author: madanalogy

replies.bodyText: That shouldn't be a problem, the file/payloads will not have millions of entries.
replies.author: thc202

replies.bodyText: Gotcha, will switch to using a List then :)
replies.author: madanalogy
